intro: Paepalanthus caespititius, commonly known as the clustered puya, is a flowering plant native to the Andean regions of South America. It is a member of the Bromeliaceae family and is characterized by its rosette-forming leaves that collect water, allowing it to thrive in humid, shaded environments. The plant produces showy, spike-like inflorescences with numerous small, tubular flowers that attract pollinators such as hummingbirds and bees. Its foliage is often covered in a dense layer of trichomes, which help reduce water loss and protect against intense sunlight. Paepalanthus caespititius is a striking example of adaptive evolution in high-altitude ecosystems.
